steps.title: Ask a friend to spot you.
steps.content: Ask a friend to spot you. For the first time you do this exercise, ask another person nearby to spot you. Getting into the right starting position can be a little tricky, so it’s best to have someone there to help you if you’ve never done this before. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Choose a weight that isn’t too heavy.
steps.content: Choose a weight that isn’t too heavy. For safety reasons, start out with a weight that you know won’t be too heavy for you. If you can’t lift the weight above your head, choose something lighter. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Stand or lie back on a bench set at an incline you feel comfortable with.
steps.content: Stand or lie back on a bench set at an incline you feel comfortable with. This exercise can be done standing or seated on a bench. Lying on a bench puts less pressure on your back, so this can be good if you’re prone to back pain. If you’re standing, keep your feet shoulder-width apart and your back as straight as possible. If you’re using a bench, keep your back straight while leaning against the bench and contract your core. Your feet should be flat against the floor. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Hold the barbell above your head with a narrow, overhand grip.
steps.content: Hold the barbell above your head with a narrow, overhand grip. Keep your core tight as you lift the barbell. [4] X Research source Fully extend your arms. Extend your thumbs along the length of the bar. If your thumbs can touch, this is the right width. Your hands should be about 8 to 12 in (20 to 30 cm) apart, so it’s a pretty close grip. [5] X Research source If you’re struggling to get into position, ask a friend to hand you the bar from behind. This can be especially helpful if you’re using pretty heavy weights. [6] X Research source If you’re using an EZ curl bar, place your hands along the angled grooves of the bar. For this exercise, the curl bar tends to be easier to grip than a regular barbell. [7] X Research source This is because it lets you hold your wrists at a more natural angle.

steps.title: Lower the bar slowly behind your head with your elbows tucked in.
steps.content: Lower the bar slowly behind your head with your elbows tucked in. Keep your elbows tightly tucked in against your head and lower the bar to the lowest point possible behind your head. You will feel a nice stretch in your triceps as you lower the bar. Don’t let your elbows flare out to the sides, because this can make the exercise less effective. [8] X Research source Keep your elbows facing forward to the best of your ability. If you’re on a bench and your lower back lifts slightly as you lower the weight, this is a sign you either need to engage your core. If your core is contracted, it may that you're lifting too much weight. Drop weight until you can keep your lower back flush with the bench.

steps.title: Push the bar back up over the back of your head, straightening your arms.
steps.content: Push the bar back up over the back of your head, straightening your arms. Extend your arms and return to your starting position, but don’t lock out your elbows. This can damage your joints. [9] X Research source Always lift slowly and smoothly, staying in control. This means not swinging the bar upward or letting the weight drop too quickly. [10] X Research source Focus on keeping your body as still as possible — only your forearms should be moving! [11] X Research source

steps.title: Inhale through your nose into your belly as you lower the bar.
steps.content: Inhale through your nose into your belly as you lower the bar. Breathe deeply into your diaphragm, which is located around your stomach. Don’t breathe with just your chest muscles, because these aren’t the primary muscles associated with breathing. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Exhale through your mouth as you lift the bar.
steps.content: Exhale through your mouth as you lift the bar. Breathe out as you’re working against gravity. [13] X Research source Never, ever hold your breath while you’re lifting! This can actually raise your blood pressure. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat this lift for 3-5 sets of 6-10 reps.
steps.content: Repeat this lift for 3-5 sets of 6-10 reps. To build muscle, start with a lighter weight warm-up set of 10-15 reps. Then, go for 3-5 fully weighted sets of 6-10 reps each. [15] X Research source However, if you don’t feel like you’re capable of that just yet or you want to do more reps, it’s perfectly fine! Just focus on maintaining your form and do the amount that you feel comfortable with. You can also try other upper body and arm exercises like tricep curls, lat pulldowns, push-ups, and bench presses. Reader Poll: We asked 366 wikiHow readers and only 11% said that the best exercise for building arm strength is a bench press . [Take Poll] So if your main goal is building up your arms, focus on one of the other exercises first.
